content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Brian Mcqueeney: Well, I was born in Charleston, South Carolina, and I've always had a deep connection to the Lowcountry. Growing up on Magnolia Lane, I remember the smell of the saltwater air and the sound of the gulls in the distance. My parents were both hardworking—my dad was a teacher with a bachelor's degree, and my mom worked as a nurse and went on to earn her graduate degree. We lived in a modest home, but it was always filled with love and laughter. I was the oldest of two kids, and I had a younger sister who's a few years behind me. We grew up in a tight-knit community, and I always felt supported by my family and friends. I went to a local public school, and while I wasn't the most academic student, I did well enough to get into a state university. I studied business, which I thought would be a good path for stability. After college, I landed a job in sales, and I've been working full time ever since. I married my wife, Sarah, a few years ago, and we've built a life together here in Charleston. We have a small home, two dogs, and we enjoy the slower pace of life compared to the hustle of the city. I'm a conservative guy, and I think that's shaped a lot of my views on family, work, and the importance of community. Life hasn't been without its challenges, but I've always tried to stay grounded and grateful for what I have.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Brian Mcqueeney: Yeah, there was definitely a crossroads. I was about to graduate from college, and I had two offers on the table—one was a stable job with a local company here in Charleston, and the other was an opportunity to move to Charlotte and work for a bigger firm with more potential for advancement. I was torn because I loved Charleston, my family, and the life I had built here. But I also knew that if I stayed, I might be stuck in the same role for years. I talked it over with my parents, and my mom, being the practical one, reminded me that sometimes you have to take a risk to grow. I ended up taking the job in Charlotte. It was tough at first—leaving my sister, my friends, and the familiar surroundings. But that experience taught me a lot about resilience and adaptability. A few years later, I realized I missed the slower pace and the community feel of Charleston. I came back, and I'm glad I did. That decision shaped who I am today—someone who values both growth and the importance of home.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Brian Mcqueeney: I think it was a conscious choice, but not one I made lightly. I weighed the pros and cons for weeks, talked to people I trusted, and even went on a few interviews in Charlotte just to get a better sense of what I was getting into. I didn't want to make a decision based on fear or uncertainty. I wanted to make sure I was choosing the path that would challenge me but still align with my values. In the end, I felt like I had the strength to take that step, and I did. I believe in making deliberate choices, even when they're hard. Life is too short to just let things happen without thinking about what you really want.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Brian Mcqueeney: Absolutely, I think having someone to talk to during those kinds of decisions can make all the difference. My mom was a big influence in that moment—she had been through her own crossroads in her career, and she gave me a lot of perspective. I also reached out to a few mentors from college who had made similar moves. They shared their experiences, both the good and the hard parts, which helped me see the bigger picture. I don't think I would have made the decision as confidently without that support. It's important to lean on people when you're at a crossroads, even if you think you can handle it alone. Sometimes, the right advice can help you see a path you didn't realize was there.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Brian Mcqueeney: Yes, I'm married to Sarah, and we've been together for almost a decade. We met in college, actually—she was studying nursing, and I was in business. We had our fair share of ups and downs, but we always found our way back to each other. We got married right after I moved back to Charleston from Charlotte, and we've built a life here that feels like home. We have two kids, a son and a daughter, both in elementary school. Our son, Ethan, is into sports—he plays soccer and baseball, and he's got that competitive fire that I think he got from me. Our daughter, Lily, is more of a bookworm; she loves reading and drawing. We have two dogs, Max and Bella, who are like part of the family. Sarah and I both work full time, but we make it a priority to have dinner together most nights and to be there for our kids. Family is everything to me, and I think that's something I learned growing up watching my parents. They always put their family first, and I want to pass that down to my kids.

Looking back on the recent interview topics from questions 1 to 5, I realize how much my journey has been shaped by the people and choices I've made along the way. From growing up in Charleston with a strong family foundation to making the difficult decision to move to Charlotte for growth, each experience has taught me something valuable. I'm grateful for the support of my parents, especially my mom, who encouraged me to take risks when I needed to. Being married to Sarah and raising our two kids has reinforced the importance of family and home, something I learned from watching my own parents. It's amazing how the questions brought me full circle, reminding me of where I came from and how far I've come—all while staying grounded in the values that matter most.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Brian Mcqueeney: My immediate family includes my parents, my younger sister, and my wife Sarah's family. My dad, John, is still living in Charleston—he retired from teaching a few years back and now spends his time gardening and volunteering at the local community center. He's always been a big part of my life, even after I moved away. My mom, Margaret, still works part-time as a nurse, though she's slowing down a bit. She's the one who always keeps our family connected, whether it's through holiday dinners or just checking in on us. My sister, Claire, is a few years younger than me, and she's a teacher now, just like Dad. We're close, even though we don't see each other as often as we'd like. She's married with a daughter of her own, and I love being an uncle to her kid. As for Sarah's family, her parents live just outside of Charleston too. They've been a big support to us, especially when we first started our family. Her dad, Mark, is a retired firefighter, and her mom, Linda, is a school administrator. They've always welcomed us into their lives, and I feel lucky to have them as part of our family circle.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Brian Mcqueeney: Outside of my family, there are a few friends who have been really important to me over the years. One of them is my college roommate, Jake. We were pretty close back then, and even though we went different paths after graduation—he ended up in tech in Atlanta, while I went into sales—our friendship has stayed strong. We still keep in touch, and I make it a point to visit him whenever I can. He's always been the more adventurous one, and I think he helped me see the value in taking risks, even if I didn't realize it at the time. Then there's my pastor, Pastor David, who's been a spiritual guide for me and Sarah. He's helped us navigate some tough times, especially when we were first starting our family. I also have a few coworkers who have become good friends over the years—people I can count on for advice or just a laugh. I think it's important to have people in your life who challenge you, support you, and remind you why you're doing what you're doing. Life is better with good friends around.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Brian Mcqueeney: I live in a quiet neighborhood just a few miles outside of downtown Charleston, in a small suburb called West Ashley. It's a mix of older homes and newer developments, but there's a real sense of community here. Most of the neighbors know each other, and it's not uncommon to see people walking their dogs or chatting in the front yards. The streets are lined with oak trees, and there's a peaceful, Southern charm to the place. I live in a two-story house with a small backyard where the kids play, and we have a nice little porch where we sit in the evenings. It's not too far from the beach, which is a big plus—Sarah and I love taking the kids down there on weekends. The local schools are good, and the community events, like the annual festival in the fall, bring everyone together. It's a place where life feels slower, more intentional, and that's exactly what I want for my family.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Brian Mcqueeney: I definitely feel safe here. It's one of the things that drew me back to Charleston after Charlotte. There's a real sense of watchfulness in the neighborhood—people look out for each other. I've never had any issues with crime, and the local police department is pretty responsive. Even at night, I feel comfortable walking around the block, especially with the streetlights and the fact that most houses have lights on when they're home. It's not just the physical safety, though—it's the feeling of being part of something bigger, where you know your neighbors and they know you. That kind of community connection makes you feel secure in more ways than one.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Brian Mcqueeney: Living here has been mostly positive, but like anywhere, there are challenges. The pace of life is slower, which I love, but that can sometimes feel like it goes against the fast-moving world out there. I've noticed that some of my friends who moved here from bigger cities have a hard time adjusting to the lack of certain amenities or the more laid-back attitude. For me, though, it's been a good fit. I enjoy the sense of community and the fact that we're not constantly rushing from one thing to the next. That said, there are moments when I feel like I'm missing out on opportunities that might be available in a bigger city. But honestly, I think the trade-off is worth it. I get to be present for my kids' lives, and I feel like I'm raising them in a place that values family and tradition. I also enjoy the local culture—whether it's the food, the festivals, or just the way people interact with each other. It's not perfect, but I wouldn't trade it for anything.

Looking back on the recent interview topics from questions 6 to 10, I realize how much my sense of family and community has shaped my current life and the environment I choose to live in. Talking about my family—Sarah, our kids, and the support we receive from both our families—reminded me of how deeply rooted I am in the values I grew up with. It's not just about the people in my life, but also the place we've chosen to build our future. Living in West Ashley has given us a safe, welcoming neighborhood where we can raise our kids with a sense of security and belonging. Even though there are challenges, like the slower pace of life or the lack of certain urban conveniences, the trade-off is worth it. I feel grounded here, surrounded by loved ones and a community that feels like home. It's amazing how these conversations brought me back to what matters most—family, safety, and the kind of life I want to create for my children.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Brian Mcqueeney: A typical week for me is pretty consistent, but there are definitely some variations depending on work and family commitments. I start my week early—usually around 6:30 a.m.—with a quick workout at the local gym. I've been trying to stay active, and the gym has a good community feel, which helps keep me motivated. After that, I get the kids ready for school, and we head out. I drop them off, then head to the office. My job is in sales, so I spend a lot of time on the phone, meeting with clients, and attending meetings. Mondays are usually the busiest day because that's when we review the week's goals and strategies. Midweek tends to be a bit more routine, but I try to make time for lunch with coworkers or a quick visit to one of the local cafes. Fridays are a bit different—after work, I usually pick up the kids and we have a family dinner. We like to have a special meal on Fridays, sometimes at a local restaurant or just cooking something at home. On weekends, we try to do something fun—whether it's going to the beach, visiting a park, or just relaxing at home. I also make sure to set aside some time for reading or working on personal projects, like fixing up the old porch swing or planning a family trip. It's not perfect, but it's a rhythm that works for us, and I'm grateful for the balance it brings to our lives.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Brian Mcqueeney: I work in sales for a mid-sized company that specializes in industrial equipment. My job is pretty demanding—it requires a lot of client interaction, relationship-building, and staying on top of industry trends. I work a standard Monday through Friday schedule, usually from 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., though I often end up working a bit later on some days, especially when I'm closing a deal or preparing for a big presentation. I've been in this role for about six years now, and while it's not the most glamorous job, it's stable and allows me to support my family. I enjoy the challenge of it, and I've learned a lot about communication and negotiation over the years. The best part is that I get to work with a great team of people who are all driven and passionate about what we do. It's not always easy, but I feel like I'm making a difference in my own way, and that keeps me motivated.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Brian Mcqueeney: Outside of work and family, I also have a few personal routines that help me stay grounded. I try to read a book every week, usually something non-fiction—history or personal development. I find that it helps me reflect and learn from others' experiences. I also enjoy working on small home projects, like fixing things around the house or tending to our garden. It's a way to disconnect from the busyness of work and just focus on something tangible. I also make it a point to attend church regularly, which is important for my faith and for staying connected with our community. On weekends, when the kids are at school or with friends, I sometimes take long walks by the river or go fishing with a few friends. It's those little moments that remind me why I chose this life—simple, intentional, and full of the things that matter most.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Brian Mcqueeney: Well, the biggest change to my daily routine has been adjusting to the kids starting school full-time. Before, when they were in preschool, I had more flexibility with my work schedule, but now I have to be more structured. I've started waking up earlier to get the kids ready and make sure we're all out the door on time. I've also been more intentional about meal planning, since we're eating at home more often now. On weeknights, I've taken on more of the cooking duties while Sarah works late a few times a week. It's been a learning curve, but it's also given me a chance to reconnect with the kids during breakfast and dinner, which I really appreciate. I've also started setting aside time each evening to read to them before bed, which has been a nice way to wind down and bond as a family. It's not the same as before, but I think it's a change that's ultimately helping us grow closer.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Brian Mcqueeney: A typical weekday for the kids starts around 7:00 a.m. with breakfast, which we usually have together as a family. After that, they get ready for school—packing their backpacks, getting dressed, and making sure they have everything they need for the day. They both go to the same elementary school, which is just a few blocks away from our house. The school day runs from 8:00 a.m. to 3:00 p.m., and they usually come home with some homework or a project they're working on. After school, Ethan tends to head straight to soccer practice, which is three times a week, while Lily usually stays for a bit longer and then goes to the library or a small after-school program where they do art and reading. I try to pick them up whenever I can, but sometimes Sarah does it if she's not working late. On days when they don't have activities, we like to have a family dinner together, and we often play board games or watch a movie. It's a busy but rewarding routine, and I love seeing them grow and learn every day.

Looking back on the recent interview topics from questions 11 to 15, I realize how much my daily life and routines are shaped by the values I hold dear—family, community, and intentionality. Talking about my neighborhood and the sense of safety it provides reminded me of how important it is to live in a place where I feel connected and secure. Reflecting on my job and the responsibilities that come with it, I see how my career supports the life I want to build for my family. The routines I've developed, from morning workouts to family dinners and weekend activities, are all part of a rhythm that keeps me grounded. It's amazing how these conversations have helped me see the bigger picture of my life—how every choice, from where I live to how I spend my time, is rooted in the values I grew up with and the life I want to create for my children.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Brian Mcqueeney: In terms of my health, I'd say I've been pretty fortunate. I've always tried to stay active, which is why I make it a point to work out a few times a week—usually a mix of cardio and strength training. I've never had any major health issues, which I think is a blessing. My parents both have a history of high blood pressure, so I've been conscious about my diet and stress levels. I try to eat a balanced diet, though I'll admit I'm not perfect—there are definitely days when I grab a fast-food burger or skip a meal when I'm busy. I do take my medications for cholesterol when needed, and I see my doctor regularly for checkups. I also make sure to get enough sleep, which I know is important for everything from my mood to my energy levels. Overall, I feel pretty good, and I think a lot of that has to do with the lifestyle I've built—staying active, eating reasonably well, and having a strong support system in my family and friends. I know I'm not immune to health issues, but I'm doing my best to stay on top of it.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Brian Mcqueeney: What makes it easy to stay healthy, I think, is having a routine that fits into my life without feeling like a burden. The morning workouts, the family dinners, and the time I spend outdoors—it all adds up to a lifestyle that supports well-being. But what makes it hard is the occasional slip-up, like when I'm working late and grab a quick bite from the vending machine or skip a workout because I'm tired. I also struggle with staying consistent when life gets busy, especially with the kids' schedules and work demands. But honestly, the biggest challenge isn't the physical part—it's the mental one. Stress can creep in, and I've learned that I need to manage it through prayer, time with family, and even just taking a walk by the river. It's not always easy, but I've come to see health as more than just physical fitness; it's about balance, and I'm learning every day how to maintain that.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Brian Mcqueeney: In the past two years, I've been pretty lucky in terms of health, but there was one incident that stands out. About a year ago, I started experiencing some back pain after a long day at work, which I initially dismissed as just being tired. But it got worse over a few weeks, and I finally made an appointment with my doctor. Turns out, I had a minor herniated disc in my lower back. It wasn't anything too serious, but it did require some physical therapy and a few weeks of adjusting my routine to avoid aggravating it. I had to take a short break from lifting heavy things at work and focus more on stretching and strengthening exercises. It was a bit of a setback, but it also reminded me how important it is to listen to my body. Since then, I've been more mindful of my posture and have started doing some yoga to keep my back strong. I'm feeling much better now, and I'm grateful that it wasn't something more severe. It was a wake-up call, and I've made it a priority to stay on top of my health moving forward.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Brian Mcqueeney: Honestly, the back issue did make things a little more challenging for a while. I had to adjust how I moved around at work, which was tough because my job does involve some physical activity, like carrying files or setting up displays for meetings. It also meant I had to be more careful with how I lifted things at home, which was a bit of an adjustment. The hardest part was knowing that I couldn't just push through the pain like I usually do. I had to slow down and take time to recover, which wasn't easy when I had a lot on my plate with work and family. But in the end, it forced me to be more intentional about how I take care of myself, and that's been a good thing. I still have moments where I feel the strain, especially after a long day, but I've learned to manage it with stretches, yoga, and just taking breaks when I need to. It reminded me that health isn't just about being strong—it's about being smart about how you use your body and taking the time to care for it, even when life gets busy.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Brian Mcqueeney: Over the past year, I've felt a lot of gratitude for the little things that make life meaningful. It's been a year of growth for our family—both the kids are settling into their routines at school, and we've been able to build some really strong friendships in the neighborhood. I've also felt a deeper sense of purpose in my work, especially as I've taken on more leadership responsibilities at the company. There were definitely moments of stress, especially with the back injury and the demands of work and family, but I've learned to lean on my faith, my family, and the people I trust. I've also found joy in the small moments—whether it's watching Ethan score a goal in soccer or Lily reading me a story before bed. Life hasn't been without its challenges, but I feel more grounded than ever, and I'm really looking forward to what the future holds for us.

Looking back on the recent interview topics from questions 16 to 20, I realize how much my health and daily routines are intertwined with the life I've built for my family. Adjusting to the kids starting school full-time has changed my schedule, but it's also given me more opportunities to be present for them, whether it's through breakfast, dinner, or bedtime stories. At the same time, I've had to confront some health challenges, like my back injury, which reminded me that taking care of my body is just as important as taking care of my family. It's not always easy to stay healthy—there are days when I slip up or feel overwhelmed—but I've come to see it as part of the balance I'm trying to maintain. Health isn't just about avoiding problems; it's about being intentional with how I live, work, and care for the people I love. These conversations have helped me reflect on how far I've come and how much I still have to learn about living a life that's both strong and sustainable.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Brian Mcqueeney: Honestly, I haven't struggled with depression or anxiety in the way some people do, but I think everyone has their moments of doubt or stress. Life with a family, a job, and the responsibilities that come with it can be overwhelming at times. There were definitely days when I felt the weight of it all—especially during the back injury or when work was particularly demanding. But I've always tried to stay grounded in my faith and in the support of my family. I think the key for me has been not ignoring those feelings when they come up, but instead talking about them, whether with Sarah, my pastor, or even just journaling about them. I've learned that it's okay to feel stressed or unsure sometimes, as long as I don't let it take over. I think that's why I've always valued community and connection so much—it's a reminder that I'm not alone in this, and that there's always someone who cares and can help.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Brian Mcqueeney: For our family, the past year has been a mix of growth, challenges, and moments of deep connection. Sarah and I have both been navigating the demands of our jobs while trying to be present for the kids, and it's been a learning process for all of us. The kids have been adjusting well to school, but there were definitely some rough patches—like when Ethan was struggling with team dynamics in soccer or when Lily had a tough time with a school project. But through it all, we've leaned on each other and the support of our friends and family. We've also made some new friends in the neighborhood, and it's been nice to have that sense of community again. Sarah has been doing a lot of extra work at her job, which has meant more late nights for her, but we've made it a point to have quality time together whenever we can. I think the biggest thing for our family is that we've all learned to be more patient with each other and to celebrate the small victories. Whether it's Ethan scoring his first goal or Lily finishing a book, those moments remind us why we're doing this—raising our kids in a place where they can grow, be safe, and feel loved.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Brian Mcqueeney: For me, religion has always been a cornerstone of my life. Growing up in a Protestant household, I was raised with strong values—things like honesty, hard work, and the importance of family. My mom was the one who really emphasized faith in our home, and even though my dad was more laid-back about it, he always respected that part of our lives. I remember sitting in church on Sunday mornings, listening to the pastor speak about love and forgiveness, and thinking about how those lessons applied to the world around me. As I got older, I started to see faith not just as something I did on Sunday, but as a way of living—guiding my choices, helping me stay grounded during tough times, and reminding me that I'm not alone in this life. Being part of a church community has also been a huge part of my sense of belonging, especially here in Charleston. We have a strong group of people who support each other, and that sense of connection is something I really value. I don't claim to have all the answers, but I do believe that faith helps me stay focused on what truly matters—my family, my community, and the life I'm trying to build for my kids.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Brian Mcqueeney: To be honest, I don't use social media all that much. I've always been more of a person who prefers face-to-face interactions or even a good phone call. I do have a Facebook account, mostly to keep in touch with family and old friends, but I don't spend a lot of time scrolling through posts or getting caught up in the news cycles. I think there's a lot of value in being present in real life, especially with the kids growing up so fast. I've noticed that some of my friends get really caught up in social media, comparing their lives to others, and I think that can be distracting. For me, it's more about what's happening right here, right now—with my family, my neighborhood, and the people I care about. I do follow a few local pages for community events or church updates, but that's about it. I think it's important to have boundaries, and for me, limiting my time online helps me stay focused on what really matters.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Brian Mcqueeney: Honestly, I don't rely on social media for emotional or financial support. I think my support system is pretty solid in real life—my family, my church community, and the people I've known for years. When things get tough, I turn to them first. I remember when I was dealing with the back injury, it was my wife Sarah who reminded me to take it easy, and my pastor who encouraged me to keep faith in the process. I think there's something about face-to-face support that just feels more genuine. I've seen people get lost in online communities, trying to find validation or help, but for me, it's always been about the people I know and trust. I'm not saying social media doesn't have its place, but for me, it's not where I go when I need support. I go to the people who've been there for me all along.

Looking back on the recent interview topics from questions 21 to 25, I realize how much my health and emotional well-being are intertwined with the life I've built for my family. The back injury was a wake-up call, reminding me that taking care of my body is just as important as taking care of my family. It wasn't easy adjusting to the changes it brought, but it also gave me a chance to slow down and be more intentional about how I live. I've learned that health isn't just about avoiding problems—it's about being smart about how I use my body and taking the time to care for it, even when life gets busy. At the same time, I've come to appreciate the importance of emotional resilience. Life with a family, a job, and the responsibilities that come with it can be overwhelming at times, but I've learned to lean on my faith, my family, and the people I trust. I've also learned that it's okay to feel stressed or unsure sometimes, as long as I don't let it take over. These experiences have helped me grow, and I'm grateful for the lessons they've taught me about balance, care, and the importance of connection in both my health and my life.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Brian Mcqueeney: In the past year, I've noticed that my stress levels have been more manageable, largely because I've been more intentional about how I handle challenges. I used to think that pushing through was the only way to get things done, but I've learned that taking a step back and breathing can make a big difference. I've started incorporating more mindfulness into my daily routine—whether it's a few deep breaths before starting my workday or a short walk after dinner to clear my mind. I also find that talking things through with Sarah or my pastor helps me process what's on my mind. I've even started journaling a bit more, just to get my thoughts out and see things from a different perspective. It's not always easy, but I've come to see emotional resilience as something you build over time, and I'm grateful for the tools I've developed to cope with life's ups and downs.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Brian Mcqueeney: In terms of making ends meet, we've always been pretty budget-conscious, especially with two kids and the costs that come with raising a family. Last month, our biggest expenses were related to the kids' school supplies, extracurricular activities, and groceries. Ethan's soccer fees and Lily's art classes added up, and we also had to replace some of the furniture in the living room after our dog, Max, knocked over a lamp. Groceries are always a big part of the budget, especially with two kids who are always hungry. We also have car payments, insurance, and utilities to consider. To manage, we try to plan meals ahead of time, use coupons when we can, and avoid unnecessary spending. Sarah and I both work full time, so we're fortunate to have a stable income, but it's always a balancing act. I think the key for us has been prioritizing what's most important—our family, our home, and our health—and making sure we don't overspend on things that don't really matter in the long run.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Brian Mcqueeney: Our household spending last month was around $4,200, which is pretty much in line with what we usually spend each month. The majority of that goes to housing—our mortgage, property taxes, and home insurance. That's the biggest chunk, and it's something we've always had to be careful with, especially since we're in a growing area where property values are rising. Then there's the car payments—Sarah and I both have cars, and we're lucky to have good rates on our loans. Groceries are another big part of the budget, especially with two kids who are always eating. We also have health insurance premiums, which can be a bit of a hit, but it's something we can't skip. We also set aside money for savings, even if it's just a small amount each month. I think the key for us is that we don't live beyond our means, and we make sure we're always planning ahead. It's not always easy, but we've learned to prioritize what's important and cut back on things that aren't.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Brian Mcqueeney: We own our home. It's a two-story house on a quiet street in West Ashley, and it's been our family's home for the past five years. Buying it was a big decision, but it felt right at the time. We were tired of renting and wanted a place where we could put down roots, especially with the kids coming along. The mortgage payment is a significant part of our budget, but we've always been careful with our finances. We also made some improvements to the house over the years—like updating the kitchen and adding a new deck in the backyard. It's not perfect, but it's a place that feels like home, and that's what matters most. I think owning a home has given us a sense of stability, and it's something I hope to pass on to my kids one day.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Brian Mcqueeney: Over the past year, our bills have had their ups and downs, just like the seasons. In the winter months, our heating bill went up a bit, which was expected, but we managed by keeping the thermostat a little lower and layering up with blankets. Then, when spring came, we had to pay for the kids' school supplies and uniforms, which added a few hundred dollars to our monthly expenses. Summer brought the soccer and art fees, and we also had to replace the front porch swing that our kids wore out. We also had a few unexpected costs, like a new air filter for the AC and a few minor car repairs. On the flip side, some of our bills were lower than usual—like the electricity bill in the fall when we started using the space heater less. We've also been more mindful of our spending, especially around holidays, by setting a budget and sticking to it. It's all about balance, and I think we've gotten better at planning ahead so we're not caught off guard when things change.

Looking back on the recent interview topics from questions 26 to 30, I realize how much my family's well-being and my own emotional resilience are deeply connected to the support systems I've built over the years. Talking about how my family has navigated the past year reminded me of the strength we've found in each other—whether it was helping Ethan through soccer challenges or supporting Lily through her school projects. It's also made me reflect on how important it is to have a strong sense of faith and community, especially when life gets tough. I've always believed that religion and spirituality are more than just rituals; they're a source of guidance and comfort that help me stay grounded. At the same time, I've come to appreciate that I don't need social media to feel connected or supported. My real-life relationships—with my wife, my kids, my church, and my neighbors—are what truly matter. These conversations have helped me see that emotional well-being isn't about perfection, but about having the right people in your life and knowing when to lean on them.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Brian Mcqueeney: I try to save as much as I can, even if it's just a small amount each month. We have a savings account that we contribute to regularly, and we also set aside some money in a separate jar for unexpected expenses, like car repairs or home maintenance. I think it's important to have a financial cushion, especially with two kids and the costs that come with raising a family. Sarah and I both agree that saving is a priority, even if it means cutting back on some things we might want. We've also been working on building an emergency fund, which has been a goal of ours for a few years now. It's not always easy, but I've learned that saving is just another part of the responsibility that comes with adulthood. I want my kids to grow up knowing that planning for the future is just as important as enjoying the present, and I think that starts with how we handle our money today.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Brian Mcqueeney: In the last year, I've been saving for both a rainy day and for bigger goals. We've been working on building our emergency fund, which has been a priority for us, especially with the kids growing up and the unexpected costs that come with that. I also started saving for a family trip—something we've wanted to do for a while now. We've been setting aside a little bit each month, and it's been a good way to have something to look forward to. On top of that, we've been saving for the kids' future, like college funds and maybe even some investments. I think it's important to have both short-term and long-term savings, and I'm glad we've been making progress in both areas. It's not about having a lot, but about being prepared and giving our kids the best chance we can.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Brian Mcqueeney: In my current occupation, I work as a sales representative for a mid-sized company that specializes in industrial equipment. My job involves a lot of client interaction, relationship-building, and staying on top of industry trends. The most important activities in my role are meeting with clients to understand their needs, presenting solutions that fit their operations, and negotiating contracts that are mutually beneficial. I also spend a significant amount of time on the phone, following up with leads, and coordinating with our technical team to ensure that our clients get the right products and support. One of the most rewarding parts of my job is seeing a deal through from the initial conversation to the final sign-off—it's satisfying to know that my work helps businesses run more efficiently. At the same time, it's a demanding job that requires a lot of communication skills, patience, and the ability to think on my feet. I've learned over the years that success in sales isn't just about closing deals—it's about building trust and understanding what makes each client tick. That's what keeps me motivated and coming back to work every day.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Brian Mcqueeney: I usually work around 45 to 50 hours a week, though it can vary depending on the time of year and how many deals we're closing. During busy seasons, like the beginning of the fiscal quarter, I might work closer to 60 hours, but I try to balance that with time for my family. I've learned that while my job is important, it's not everything. I make it a point to leave work at a reasonable hour most days, especially on Fridays, so I can be there for the kids and have dinner with Sarah. I also take weekends off as much as possible, unless there's a big client meeting or a presentation coming up. It's a demanding job, but I've found a way to make it work without sacrificing the things that matter most—family, faith, and the slower, more intentional pace of life here in Charleston.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Brian Mcqueeney: No, I haven't had more than one job. I've been focused on my career in sales for the past six years, and while it's demanding, it's been the right fit for me. I've considered taking on some side projects or consulting work in the past, especially during slower periods, but I always found myself prioritizing my family and the stability that my full-time job provides. I think having one job allows me to be more present for the kids and for Sarah, and honestly, I don't feel the need to stretch myself too thin. There's a lot of value in having a stable income and a clear work-life balance, especially with the responsibilities we have. I've always believed that success isn't just about how much you earn, but about how much you're able to enjoy the life you're building with the people you love.

Looking back on the recent interview topics from questions 31 to 35, I realize how much my emotional resilience and financial stability are connected to the choices I've made over the years. Talking about my stress levels and coping strategies reminded me of how important it is to take time for myself, whether it's through mindfulness, journaling, or simply talking things through with Sarah or my pastor. It's not always easy to slow down and breathe, but I've come to see it as a necessary part of living a balanced life. At the same time, discussing our household budget and expenses brought me back to the reality of managing a family on a regular income. It's not about having more—it's about being intentional with what we have, making sure we're not living beyond our means, and always keeping our family's needs at the forefront. I've learned that financial security and emotional well-being go hand in hand, and I'm grateful for the systems we've put in place to support both. These conversations have helped me reflect on how far I've come and how much I still have to learn about building a life that's both stable and meaningful.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Brian Mcqueeney: In terms of our household income, we made around $7,500 last month, which is pretty consistent with what we usually bring in. Both Sarah and I work full time—she's a nurse at a local hospital, and I'm in sales for the industrial equipment company. Our combined income helps us cover the mortgage, the kids' expenses, and our everyday needs. It's not a huge amount, but it's enough to live comfortably here in Charleston, especially since we don't have a lot of the high costs that come with bigger cities. We also try to be smart about our money, setting aside a portion each month for savings and unexpected expenses. I think the key for us is that we're not chasing more—we're focused on what we have and making sure it's enough for the life we want to build for our family.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Brian Mcqueeney: I've been at my current job for about six years now, and I've really come to appreciate the stability and the benefits that come with it. The company offers a solid health insurance plan that covers both Sarah and me, which is a huge relief, especially with two kids. We also get a standard amount of paid time off—about two weeks of vacation, a week of personal days, and sick leave when needed. I think the best part of the benefits package is the retirement plan they offer. It's not a huge match, but it's something that helps us plan for the future. The company also has a pretty good culture—there's a sense of camaraderie among the team, and we all work hard to support each other. I've learned a lot from my coworkers, and I feel like I'm part of something bigger than just my individual performance. It's not a perfect job, but it's one that allows me to support my family and still have time for the things that matter most.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Brian Mcqueeney: My relationships at work are pretty good overall. I have a solid rapport with my manager, Mark, who's been with the company for over a decade. He's experienced, fair, and always willing to listen. He's given me a lot of autonomy in my role, which I really appreciate, and he's been a great mentor over the years. As for my coworkers, we get along well—there's a real sense of teamwork, especially during busy periods. We're all in this together, pushing to meet goals and support each other when things get tough. I've built some strong friendships with a few of them, and I think that camaraderie makes the job more enjoyable. I don't have any real conflicts, and I feel like I'm part of a supportive environment that values hard work and dedication. That kind of atmosphere makes a big difference, especially when the work can be demanding at times.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Brian Mcqueeney: My work schedule is pretty predictable, though there are some fluctuations depending on the time of year and how many deals we're pushing through. I usually start around 8:00 a.m. and finish by 5:00 p.m., but I often stay a bit later on days when I'm finalizing a contract or preparing for a big presentation. The company does offer some flexibility, especially if I need to adjust my hours for family commitments. For example, if Sarah has a late shift at the hospital, I can sometimes leave a little earlier or come in a bit later the next day. That kind of flexibility is really important to me—it helps me balance work with being there for the kids and for Sarah. I also have the option to work from home a few days a week, which is a nice perk. It's not always the most flexible job in the world, but I think the predictability of it gives me a sense of stability, which is something I really value in my life.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Brian Mcqueeney: Overall, I feel pretty good about our financial situation. We're not wealthy by any means, but we're stable, and that's what matters most to me. With both Sarah and I working full time, we're able to cover our bills, save a little each month, and still have some flexibility for things like family trips or unexpected expenses. I think the key for us has always been living within our means and being intentional about what we spend our money on. We've made some sacrifices over the years—like not buying a bigger house or driving newer cars—but I don't regret it. It's allowed us to focus on what really matters: our family, our home, and the life we're building together. I know there are days when I worry about the future, especially with the kids getting older and the costs of raising them, but I also know we're doing the best we can. I think financial security is about more than just having a lot—it's about knowing you can provide for the people you love and still have a sense of peace and purpose in your life.

Looking back on the recent interview topics from questions 36 to 40, I realize how much my financial stability and emotional resilience are intertwined with the choices I've made over the years. Talking about how our bills have fluctuated over the past year reminded me of the importance of being prepared for the unexpected—whether it's a higher heating bill in the winter or the cost of school supplies in the fall. It's not always easy to stay on top of everything, but I've learned that planning ahead and being mindful of our spending helps us navigate those ups and downs without too much stress. At the same time, discussing my work schedule and hours brought me back to the balance I've worked hard to maintain between my career and my family. I've come to see that having a stable income is important, but it's not everything. What matters most is being present for the people I love and making sure we're living a life that feels intentional and meaningful. These conversations have helped me reflect on how far I've come and how much I still have to learn about building a life that's both secure and full of purpose.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Brian Mcqueeney: Yes, both my mom and dad worked while I was growing up. My dad was a teacher, and he worked full time at a local high school for over twenty years. He was always dedicated to his students, and I remember seeing him grade papers late into the night or prepare lesson plans on weekends. My mom worked as a nurse, and she had a demanding schedule, often working shifts at the hospital. Even though she was busy, she always made time for our family—whether it was helping me with homework or taking me and my sister to the park on the weekends. They both worked hard to provide for us, and I think that's why I've always valued the importance of a stable job and financial responsibility. It wasn't always easy, but they never let us feel like we were missing out on anything. They taught me that work is important, but it's not everything—family and faith come first, and I've carried that lesson with me throughout my life.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Brian Mcqueeney: My dad was a high school teacher, and his most important activities were planning lessons, grading papers, and working closely with his students to help them succeed. He had a real passion for education, and I remember him staying late after school to help kids who were struggling or to prepare for upcoming tests. He also coached soccer for a few years, which was something I always looked forward to—watching him on the field was inspiring. My mom was a nurse, and her most important duties were caring for patients, making sure they were comfortable, and providing them with the medical attention they needed. She worked long hours, but she always made time for our family. I remember her coming home exhausted but still making sure she was there for us, whether it was helping me with homework or just sitting down for dinner. Both of them had demanding jobs, but they always made it clear that family came first. I think that's why I've always valued work-life balance so much—it's not just about what you do for a living, but how you do it and who you do it for.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Brian Mcqueeney: My dad worked for the Charleston School District, teaching high school biology and chemistry. It was a public school, and he was always passionate about making sure his students understood the material and felt supported. He spent a lot of time preparing lesson plans, grading assignments, and staying after class to help kids who needed extra support. He also coached the soccer team, which was a big part of his life. My mom worked at a local hospital as a registered nurse. She was on a rotating shift schedule, which meant she was often working nights or weekends, but she always made it a point to be there for us. I remember her coming home exhausted but still making sure she was present for dinner or helping me with my homework. Both of them had demanding jobs, but they always found a way to balance work with family. I think that's why I've always valued the importance of having a stable job while also making sure I'm there for the people I love.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Brian Mcqueeney: Looking ahead a few years, I hope to be in the same place I am now—raising my kids in a safe, loving environment where they can grow up with a strong sense of family, faith, and community. I hope we're still living in West Ashley, maybe with a few more memories made on that porch swing or at the beach. I'd like to see Ethan and Lily continue to thrive in school, maybe with Ethan playing soccer at the college level and Lily finding her passion in the arts. I also hope to have more time to focus on my health, maybe by running a 5K or two, and to be more present in the little moments that make life meaningful. Professionally, I'd like to take on more leadership roles at work, but not at the expense of my family. I hope to have a stable income that allows us to plan for the future, maybe even save a little more for their college funds or a family trip somewhere new. Most of all, I hope we're still laughing a lot, still having those late-night talks over coffee, and still feeling like we're building something real and lasting together.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Brian Mcqueeney: What I value the most in my life is family—my wife, my kids, and the relationships we've built with each other and the people around us. I think that's something I learned growing up, watching my parents put their family first no matter what. I also value faith, because it's been a constant in my life, guiding me through tough times and reminding me that I'm not alone. I value community, too—the sense of belonging we have here in West Ashley, where people look out for each other and life feels more connected. And I value the simple things—the smell of the ocean air, the sound of my kids laughing, the quiet moments on the porch with a cup of coffee. I think life is about more than just achieving goals or climbing the ladder; it's about being present, being grateful, and building something meaningful with the people you love.

Looking back on the recent interview topics from questions 41 to 45, I realize how much my work life and financial stability are intertwined with the values I hold most dear—family, faith, and community. Talking about my household income and expenses reminded me of the importance of living within our means while still providing for the needs of my family. It's not about having more money, but about being intentional with what we have and making sure it's enough for the life we want to build. Discussing my job, the benefits I receive, and the relationships I have with my coworkers and manager brought me back to the balance I've worked hard to maintain between my career and my family. I've come to see that having a stable income is important, but it's not everything. What matters most is being present for the people I love and making sure we're living a life that feels intentional and meaningful. These conversations have helped me reflect on how far I've come and how much I still have to learn about building a life that's both secure and full of purpose.

Going through this complete interview and life story has been a journey of reflection and gratitude. It reminded me of how much my life has been shaped by the people I love, the choices I've made, and the values I hold close—family, faith, and community. From growing up in Charleston with my parents' strong work ethic and devotion to our family, to making the difficult decision to move to Charlotte for growth and then returning home, each step has led me to where I am today. I've come to appreciate the balance between work and family, the importance of health and well-being, and the power of intentionality in daily life. This interview has helped me see the bigger picture of my life, not just as a series of events, but as a tapestry woven together by the relationships, routines, and values that matter most. I'm grateful for the life I've built with Sarah, our kids, and the community that supports us, and I look forward to continuing to grow and build a future filled with love, purpose, and connection.
